sub_title: Data Steward, Cultural Anthropology & Development Sociology (CAOS) / Centre for Science & Technology Studies (CWTS) / Support for Research, Laboratories and Education (SOLO)
summary:
Hi! I'm Andrew and I am a Data Steward in the Faculty of Social and Behavioral Sciences at Leiden University in the Netherlands.

In this capacity, I spend much of my time liaising with researchers and support staff in Cultural Anthropology & Development Sociology (CAOS) and the Centre for Science & Technology Studies (CWTS) to address any and all Research Data Management needs – from assisting in drafting Data Management Plans, to choosing long-term data storage/archiving, assembling Publication Packages, or any number of other facets of RDM that social science researchers encounter in their work.

Additionally, I also work closely with my team of Privacy, Security, and Data Management experts in our faculty, as well as with colleagues at Leiden's Center for Digital Scholarship, to develop resources and tooling that will assist researchers and fellow RDM professionals alike in navigating the rapidly shifting and sometimes daunting landscape of new policies, protocols, and ever more forms to fill out.
 
In my previous lives, I've been a Research Data Coordinator in academic cancer medicine (NYC, US); completed a doctoral degree in sociology with a concentration in social studies of medicine (McGill University, CA); and worked as a (sometimes-competitive) oyster shucker in the great state of Maine. I've also held a couple of postdoctoral fellowships (University of Washington, USA & Radboud University, NL), where I was studying and working alongside sociotechnical infrastructure development projects, predominantly in the field of translational science & medicine. 

It is here that I gained a keen appreciation for the promises, difficulties, and overall hard work it takes to implement concepts like Open Science and the FAIR Data Principles in everyday research practices – both in the fields that I have studied, but also in my own work as an ethnographer of knowledge infrastructures. And it was an interest in confronting these challenges as an RDM practitioner, where I could help researchers and policymakers make sense of each others' distinct epistemologies (or whatever you call it), that led me to my current work as a Data Steward.

Beyond these pursuits, I love reading novels on my morning commute to work, watching tennis in the evenings, accumulating way more LPs than I'll ever have the time to listen carefully to, and seeking out lighthouses in distant corners of the world with the partner of my dreams and the kid for whom we share responsibility.

awards.title: Margaret Lock Prize in Social Studies of Medicine
awards.description: Established in 2005 by Dr. Margaret Lock and awarded by the Faculty of Medicine Scholarships Committee upon recommendation from the Department of Social Studies in Medicine, The Margaret Lock Prize in Social Studies of Medicine is given to an outstanding student who demonstrates high academic standing in either the Medical Anthropology or Medical Sociology program.
awards.issuer: Department of Social Studies of Medicine, McGill University

awards.title: Wolfe Graduate Fellowship in Scientific and Technological Literacy
awards.description: The Wolfe Fellowship (valued at $8000) is awarded to outstanding graduate students at McGill University conducting research in areas directly related to the themes of the Wolfe Chair in Scientific and Technological Literacy. The mandate of the Wolfe Chair is to conduct research, teach and perform public outreach regarding the intellectual foundations, nature and methods of scientific and technological innovation and to provide support to well-rounded students capable of making constructive contributions to debates surrounding science, technology and society. The Chair is devoted to research that advances understanding of key scientific and technological concepts and examines the relationships among science, technology, and a broad range of social, ethical, political, and economic issues, practices and conditions.

awards.title: APOGEE-Net/CanGèneTest Doctoral Training Fellowship
awards.description:
APOGEE-Net/CanGèneTest supports the development of health policies in genetics through the creation of a research and knowledge network linking individuals engaged in the production, transmission, and utilization of knowledge in the field of genetics. It brings together partners from universities, clinical settings, advisory bodies, and government in order to efficiently address questions relevant to the development of health policies and to the organization of the healthcare system in the field of genetics.

Doctoral Training Fellowships (valued at $35,000 over two years) are awarded to outstanding doctoral students whose research projects reinforce transdisciplinary capacities and foster cross-fertilization by drawing from and integrating different research domains.
awards.issuer: APOGEE-Net/CanGèneTest Research and Knowledge Network on Genetic Health Services and Polic

awards.title: CIHR Strategic Training Fellow in Health Care, Technology, and Place (HCTP)
awards.description: The Canadian Institutes of Health Research Strategic Training Fellowship in Health Care, Technology, and Place (valued at $30,000 over two years) is awarded to doctoral students who show promise and commitment to research that is pertinent to the themes of the HCTP program. HCTP Doctoral Fellows are expected to study the interrelationships between and among at least two of the four nodes that characterize contemporary health care: health care technologies; the human body; settings used for health care; and health care work.
awards.issuer: Canadian Institutes of Health Research/University of Toronto

projects.title: What does your Personal Health Environment (PGO) look like? Exploring new approaches to sharing healthcare data
projects.description:
From June 2020, healthcare organizations are obliged to provide patients and clients with online insight into their personal health data. Personal health environments (PGOs) have been designed for this: these are digital platforms for the safe online exchange of personal health data between a healthcare organization and a citizen. PGOs would give citizens the opportunity to decide for themselves with whom they would and would not like to share their health data, which in turn would lead to better health outcomes and tailored care. At the same time, it is a challenge for the government and technology designers to design PGOs that are suitable for people with different backgrounds and (digital) skills.

With this research we want to map out how different user groups view PGOs; what they expect from such a platform; and what user needs they have. The aim of this research is to provide a clear overview of the wishes and needs of different user types. This helps policymakers and designers to develop an accessible PGO that can be used widely.

During this research, special attention is paid to the following user groups: citizens with and without chronic illness, including the elderly. Representatives of these groups are invited to a workshop dedicated to their target audience. In addition, we invite policymakers, PGO designers, medical researchers and physicians to each workshop, so that the needs of different user groups can be discussed, compared, and related.

The main output of these workshops will be a set of comic-style 'personas' and 'data sharing journeys' that capture the collectively-realized visions of who PGO users are and what their needs are (e.g. personas), as well as to situate these users in a wider ecosystem that includes not only end-users, but also clinicians, researchers, policymakers, and even PGO designers themselves (e.g. data sharing journeys.)

profile_positions.title: Research Associate, iHub - Interdisciplinary Hub for Digitalization & Society

profile_positions.description:
Assembling Data Science is a first-in-kind sociotechnical analysis of efforts to institutionalize data science at the national level in the United States. Within and across nearly every domain, it is argued that new modes of aggregating and analyzing data hold the promise of addressing the major social and scientific issues of our times: from agriculture to healthcare, and from interoperability to computational reproducibility.

Taking the NSF-funded Big Data Regional Innovation Hubs and Spokes as our point of departure, we situate this recent initiative in a much longer historical arc of large-scale and long-term research infrastructure development in the US dating back more than 50 years. From this perspective, BDHubs is a key site for analyzing the ongoing and mutual (re)shaping of policy, technological development, and organizational dynamics at the dawning of a new era of data science.

A central objective of our project is thus to characterize these changes that are occurring at the very moment the BDHubs program is being rolled out. Here, we are attentive to the strategies that the Hubs + Spokes deploy as they adapt to -- while simultaneously participate in furthering -- the enhanced capacities of information science and technologies, as well as the formation of novel institutional arrangements among government, industry, nonprofit organizations, and academia.

Unpacking large-scale, cross-sector collaborations centered on the tools and techniques of data processing and visualization motivates a fundamental insight: that the advent of data science in the US is not only indicative of a burgeoning paradigm of technical research but points to a broader institutional movement whose very unfolding warrants further exploration. Our research program establishes a coherent ethnographically-informed analytic framework for mapping technological assemblages and policy pathways, one that should find relevance to students of science, policymakers, and practitioners alike.
profile_positions.title: Research Scientist

profile_positions.location: Departments of Anthropology and Sociology / McGill University School of Medicine
profile_positions.title: Teaching Assistant / Group Leader

profile_positions.description:
Collaborated with team of medical historians and social scientists to chart the history of the Department of Human Genetics at McGill University
•	Analyzed archival materials and published literature for a comprehensive understanding of genetics as related to the technical/clinical issues in the field and to the work flows of interview subjects
•	Interviewed current and former members of the department
•	Focused on the evolution of processes and technologies during the department’s development
•	Highlighted the respective impact on the direction and outcomes of research conducted 
•	Resulted in the publication of scholarly article: ‘Medical Genetics at McGill: The History of a Pioneering Research Group.’ Canadian Bulletin of Medical History; Vol. 30, No. 1: 2013.
profile_positions.title: Co-Investigator, Department of Social Studies of Medicine

profile_positions.location: Clinical Trials Office, Leukemia & Sarcoma Services
profile_positions.description:
Assisted Principle Investigators in the capacity of research coordinator with meeting all targets for clinical studies in the Leukemia/Melanoma & Sarcoma Services, from pre-trial planning to post-trial analysis
•	Pre-launch: aided Investigators in meeting study pre-launch targets; organized all requisite internal and external regulatory documents; drafted consent, eligibility, and research authorization forms; facilitated communication between Principle Investigators, study sponsors and the hospital’s Institutional Review Board
•	Study launch: organized meetings and information sessions for all new trials in my portfolio
•	Trial accrual: attended weekly clinics and assisted Investigators and clinic nurses in recruiting prospective subjects for research studies; prepared and administered informed consent forms to new patients interested in clinical trials
•	Data management: performed abstraction of chart data from original source records; input data into relevant computer applications and databases; frequently queried data to ensure accuracy and consistency; liaised with Contract Research Organization monitoring staff on monthly site visits and aided CRO in meeting targets for drug development and regulatory approval; reviewed and addressed all monitor queries
•	Regulatory oversight: prepared weekly, monthly, quarterly, and annual reports for submission to the necessary regulatory bodies including the hospital’s Data Safety and Monitoring Committee, Therapeutic Response Review Committee, Institutional Review Board, and the US Food and Drug Administration; organized and submitted all necessary documentation for protocol amendments; ensured all Federal regulations and institutional policies were followed; maintained trial Regulatory Binders
profile_positions.title: Research Data Coordinator
